title: Tracking My Fibromyalgia Fatigue

content: This past May, I had a 2-month fibromyalgia flare-up.

Late one morning, I felt more tired than I expected. I figured it was because I’d stayed up late the night before, reading Hawaii Five-0 fanfiction and listening to the Lord of the Rings: Return of the King movie score.

At lunchtime, I ate an extra-healthy salad, drank double the water and one of those protein milkshakes, downed a can of Coke for the caffeine and sugar (ok, two cans), and took 20 milligrams of the stimulant Ritalin.
My sciatica was acting up, so I couldn’t take a walk — at least not one longer than 8 minutes. And I was too busy to take a nap.
I did what I knew might work, crossed my fingers, and hoped for the best.
Unfortunately, by mid-afternoon, the flavor changed. My tiredness turned to exhaustion.
By dinnertime, my exhaustion graduated to fatigue. I rested and got to bed early. The optimistic part of me hoped that it was nothing more than a bad day.

content: People have bad days! Then they wake up the following morning refreshed and ready to go!
But the next morning, I was the opposite of “refreshed and ready to go.”

When I woke up, it took a couple of tries to swing my legs off the bed and stand up. I felt weighed down and stiff. My legs were heavy and inflexible like thick tree trunks. I knew I needed to go into the bathroom, but it took my foggy brain a good 20 seconds to remember why.
When I told my dad I was “in a flare-up,” he asked his usual question: “What’s your number?”
I thought about it. I couldn’t sit up without fatigue yanking me back down. “40,” I replied. “No. Someone flipped a switch and doubled the force of gravity. Probably 35.”
Dad likes data. He wants to know when I’m feeling better or worse, but “I’m better” and “I’m worse” aren’t quantifiable. So in my family, we have a 1-100 scale.

content: 80, plus or minus 5-10, is considered “normal.”

If I’m 0, I’m not able to report it because I’m chilling on a cloud with my ancestors, rocking a halo, drinking a bottomless chocolate milkshake in a hot tub with Robin Williams to entertain me and Robert Downey Jr. to… Well, to look at.
I’m not sure what a 100 is. It would probably mean my Lyrica and antidepressants are in the trash. I’m down 100 pounds. Maybe I’m an immortal who doesn’t have to sleep.
Measuring my fatigue is an inexact science.
But Dad wants a number to add to the graph in his head — the one that shows I’m gradually getting better even though I’m “up and down.”
How do I know what my number is?
The truth is, I’m not sure. I listen to my body. What does that mean? The truth is … I’m not sure.
I guess I ask myself if I’m better or worse. That determines if the number from yesterday goes up or down.

content: Then I ask myself, “Am I a lot better/a lot worse?”
Usually, the change is gradual. Each day I go up or down 5%-10%. Sometimes I go up or down for 9 months.
The day we left for our summer vacation, my number was 20. I wondered if I needed to go to the hospital. The day we came back it was 65, almost 70! Thanks, Holden Beach! I needed that miracle.
